display.name: RSS3 Value Sublayer
display.description: The RSS3 Value Sublayer (VSL) as part of the RSS3 Network, is an Ethereum ScalingProject built with OP Stack, handling the value and ownership of AI and Open Information.

contract.description: Main entry point for users depositing ETH.
Main entry point for users depositing ERC20 token that do not require custom gateway.

dataAvailability.name: Data required to compute fraud proof is not published on chain, and currently not publicly accessible
dataAvailability.description: Transaction data is submitted to a blob store contract on NearDA. Only hashes of blob data is published on an onchain inbox.

references.title: Derivation: Batch submission - OP Mainnet specs

risks.text: the data is not made available on the external provider.
the sequencer posts an unavailable or malicious transaction root.

operator.name: The system has a centralized operator
operator.description: The operator is the only entity that can propose blocks. A live and trustworthy operator is vital to the health of the system.

risks.text: the operator exploits their centralized position and frontruns user transactions.

forceTransactions.name: Users can force any transaction
forceTransactions.description: Because the state of the system is based on transactions submitted on the underlying host chain and anyone can submit their transactions there it allows the users to circumvent censorship by interacting with the smart contract on the host chain directly.

exitMechanisms.name: Regular messaging
exitMechanisms.description: The user initiates L2->L1 messages by submitting a regular transaction on this chain. When the block containing that transaction is settled, the message becomes available for processing on L1. The process of block finalization takes a challenge period of 7d to complete.

risks.text: the centralized validator goes down. Users cannot produce blocks themselves and exiting the system requires new block production.

exitMechanisms.name: Forced messaging
exitMechanisms.description: If the user experiences censorship from the operator with regular L2->L1 messaging they can submit their messages directly on L1. The system is then obliged to service this request or halt all messages, including forced withdrawals from L1 and regular messages initiated on L2. Once the force operation is submitted and if the request is serviced, the operation follows the flow of a regular message.

references.title: Forced withdrawal from an OP Stack blockchain

otherConsiderations.name: EVM compatible smart contracts are supported
otherConsiderations.description: OP stack chains are pursuing the EVM Equivalence model. No changes to smart contracts are required regardless of the language they are written in, i.e. anything deployed on L1 can be deployed on L2.

roles.name: Challenger
roles.description: Allowed to challenge or delete state roots proposed by a Proposer.

roles.name: Guardian
roles.description: Allowed to pause withdrawals. In op stack systems with a proof system, the Guardian can also blacklist dispute games and set the respected game type (permissioned / permissionless).

roles.name: Proposer
roles.description: Allowed to post new state roots of the current layer to the host chain.

roles.name: Sequencer
roles.description: Allowed to commit transactions from the current layer to the host chain.

actors.name: RSS3Multisig
actors.description:
A Multisig with 3/5 threshold. 
* Can upgrade **with no delay**
  * OptimismMintableERC20Factory [via: ProxyAdmin]
  * SuperchainConfig [via: ProxyAdmin]
  * L1StandardBridge [via: ProxyAdmin]
  * OptimismPortal [via: ProxyAdmin]
  * SystemConfig [via: ProxyAdmin]
  * L1CrossDomainMessenger [via: ProxyAdmin]
  * L1ERC721Bridge [via: ProxyAdmin]
  * L2OutputOracle [via: ProxyAdmin]
* Can interact with AddressManager
  * set and change address mappings [via: ProxyAdmin]

actors.name: WithdrawalOverwriterMultisig
actors.description:
A Multisig with 3/5 threshold. 
* Can interact with OptimismPortal
  * can overwrite the calldata of any withdrawals in the OptimismPortal on finalization, potentially stealing the withdrawn funds or calling arbitrary contracts

actors.name: EOA 4
actors.description:
* Can interact with SystemConfig
  * it can update the preconfer address, the batch submitter (Sequencer) address and the gas configuration of the system

ethereum.name: SystemConfig
ethereum.description:
Contains configuration parameters such as the Sequencer address, gas limit on this chain and the unsafe block signer address.
* Roles:
  * **admin**: ProxyAdmin; ultimately RSS3Multisig
  * **batcherHash**: EOA 3
  * **owner**: EOA 4

ethereum.name: L2OutputOracle
ethereum.description:
Contains a list of proposed state roots which Proposers assert to be a result of block execution. Currently only the PROPOSER address can submit new state roots.
* Roles:
  * **admin**: ProxyAdmin; ultimately RSS3Multisig
  * **challenger**: EOA 2
  * **proposer**: EOA 1

ethereum.name: SuperchainConfig
ethereum.description:
This is NOT the shared SuperchainConfig contract of the OP stack Superchain but rather a local fork. It manages the `PAUSED_SLOT`, a boolean value indicating whether the local chain is paused, and `GUARDIAN_SLOT`, the address of the guardian which can pause and unpause the system.
* Roles:
  * **admin**: ProxyAdmin; ultimately RSS3Multisig
  * **guardian**: EOA 5

ethereum.name: L1StandardBridge
ethereum.description:
The main entry point to deposit ERC20 tokens from host chain to this chain.
* Roles:
  * **admin**: ProxyAdmin; ultimately RSS3Multisig

ethereum.name: L1CrossDomainMessenger
ethereum.description:
Sends messages from host chain to this chain, and relays messages back onto host chain. In the event that a message sent from host chain to this chain is rejected for exceeding this chain's epoch gas limit, it can be resubmitted via this contract's replay function.
* Roles:
  * **admin**: ProxyAdmin; ultimately RSS3Multisig

ethereum.name: L1ERC721Bridge
ethereum.description:
Used to bridge ERC-721 tokens from host chain to this chain.
* Roles:
  * **admin**: ProxyAdmin; ultimately RSS3Multisig

ethereum.name: OptimismPortal
ethereum.description:
The main entry point to deposit funds from host chain to this chain. It also allows to prove and finalize withdrawals. This fork of the OptimismPortal also allows an 'operator' address to overwrite the calldata of withdrawals on finalization, potentially stealing the withdrawn funds or calling arbitrary contracts.
* Roles:
  * **admin**: ProxyAdmin; ultimately RSS3Multisig
  * **guardian**: EOA 5
  * **operator**: WithdrawalOverwriterMultisig

risks.text: a contract receives a malicious code upgrade. There is no delay on code upgrades.

milestones.title: RSS3 Mainnet Alpha Launch
milestones.description: RSS3 Network Mainnet Alpha is live.

milestones.title: RSS3 starts using NearDA
milestones.description: RSS3 Network starts publishing data to NearDA.

badges.name: Built on OP Stack
badges.description: The project is built on the OP Stack

badges.name: NearDA
badges.description: This project is posting its data to NearDA

badges.name: EVM
badges.description: This project uses the Ethereum Virtual Machine to run its smart contracts and supports the Solidity programming language

reasonsForBeingOther.label: No proofs
reasonsForBeingOther.shortDescription: The proof system isn't fully functional
reasonsForBeingOther.description: Projects without a proper proof system fully rely on single entities to safely update the state. A malicious proposer can finalize an invalid state, which can cause loss of funds.

reasonsForBeingOther.label: No DA bridge
reasonsForBeingOther.shortDescription: There is no data availability bridge
reasonsForBeingOther.description: Projects without a data availability bridge fully rely on single entities (the sequencer) to honestly rely available data roots on Ethereum. A malicious sequencer can collude with the proposer to finalize an unavailable state, which can cause loss of funds.

categories.title: No state validation
categories.description: OP Stack projects can use the OP fault proof system, already being deployed on some. This project though is not using fault proofs yet and is relying on the honesty of the permissioned Proposer and Challengers to ensure state correctness. The smart contract system permits invalid state roots.

risks.text: an invalid state root is submitted to the system.

stateValidation.description: Currently the system permits invalid state roots. More details in project overview.

exitWindow.description: There is no window for users to exit in case of an unwanted regular upgrade since contracts are instantly upgradable.

proposerFailure.description: Only the whitelisted proposers can publish state roots on L1, so in the event of failure the withdrawals are frozen.

dataAvailability.description: Proof construction and state derivation rely fully on data that is NOT published on chain.

sequencerFailure.description: In the event of a sequencer failure, users can force transactions to be included in the project's chain by sending them to L1. There can be up to a 12h delay on this operation.

layer.description: The data is posted to NearDA which is a separate data availability layer on the Near protocol. Only hashes of data are published on an onchain inbox.

bridge.description: There is no bridge that can attest if the data has been made available.
